revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1602|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1602'''.
==Events== *[[February 2]] – The [[Lord Chamberlain's Men]] perform ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' at the [[Middle Temple]] in London. *May – [[Henry Wotton]] returns to [[Florence]] having disclosed a plot to murder King [[James VI of Scotland]].<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Wotton, Henry|last=Lee|first=Sidney|authorlink=Sidney Lee|volume=63}}</ref> *[[May 4]] – [[Richard Hakluyt]] is installed as prebendary of [[Dean and Chapter of Westminster|Westminster Abbey]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard S. Westfall|title=Hakluyt, Richard|url=http://galileo.rice.edu/Catalog/NewFiles/hakluyt.html|publisher=The Galileo Project|year=1995|accessdate=21 April 2007}}</ref> *[[November 8]] – The [[Bodleian Library]] at the [[University of Oxford]] opens to scholars.
==New books== ===Prose=== *Tommaso Campanella – ''[[The City of the Sun]]'' (a philosophical work, one of the most important utopias) *[[Thomas Campion]] – ''Observations in the Art of English Poetry'' *[[Richard Carew (antiquary)|Richard Carew]] – ''A Survey of Cornwall'' *Sir [[Hugh Plat]] – ''[[Delightes for Ladies]]'' (book of recipes and household hints)
===Drama=== *Anonymous – ''[[A Larum for London|A Larum for London, or The Siedge of Antwerpe with the]]'' ''{{not a typo|ventrous}} actes and valorous deeds of the lame soldier'' published *[[Henry Chettle]] – ''Hoffmann'' *[[John Davies of Hereford]] – ''Mirum in Modum'' *[[Thomas Dekker (poet)|Thomas Dekker]] (with [[Thomas Middleton]]?) – ''[[Blurt, Master Constable|Blurt, Master Constable, or The Spaniards Night-Walke]]'' published *[[Ben Jonson]] – ''[[The Poetaster]]'' published *[[David Lyndsay (poet)|Sir David Lyndsay]] (died c. 1555) – ''Humanity and Sensuality'' and ''[[A Satire of the Three Estates]]'' published *[[John Marston (poet)|John Marston]] – ''[[Antonio and Mellida]]'' published *[[William Shakespeare]] – ''[[Hamlet]]'' performed (latest date), ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'' published *"W.S." – ''[[Thomas Lord Cromwell]]'' published<ref name="RSC Collab">{{cite book|author=Shakespeare, William|title=Collaborative Plays|series=The RSC Shakespeare|location=Basingstoke|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|year=2013|isbn=978-1-137-27144-0|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
===Poetry=== {{main|1602 in poetry}} *[[Giambattista Marino]] – ''Le Rime'' *[[Cristóbal de Virués]] – ''El Monserrate segundo''
==Births== *[[March 29]] – [[John Lightfoot]], English theologian (died [[1675 in literature|1675]]) *[[April 30]] – [[Robert Baillie]], Scottish divine and historian (died [[1662 in literature|1662]]) *[[May 2]] – [[Athanasius Kircher]], German scholar (died [[1680 in literature|1680]]) *[[May 10]] – [[Samuel Newman]], American Biblical commentator (died [[1663 in literature|1663]]) *October or November – [[Dudley North, 4th Baron North|Dudley North]], English poet, writer and politician (died [[1677 in literature|1677]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Juan Pérez de Montalbán]], Spanish dramatist and poet (died [[1638 in literature|1638]]) *''Approximate year'' – [[Owen Feltham]], English essayist (died [[1668 in literature|1668]])
==Deaths== *[[February 13]] – [[Alexander Nowell]], English theologian (born c. 1507) *[[September 14]] – [[Jean Passerat]], French poet and satirist (born [[1534 in literature|1534]]) *[[October 13]] – [[Franciscus Junius (the elder)]], Swiss theologian (born [[1545 in literature|1545]]) *[[October 30]] – [[Jean-Jacques Boissard]], French poet (born [[1528 in literature|1528]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Jean Pithou]], French legal writer (born [[1534 in literature|1534]])
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1602 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

revision.text:
[[File:Alfeñiques or sugar fugures.jpg|250px|thumb|Assortment of alfeñiques for ''[[Día de Muertos]].]]
An '''alfeñique''' is a [[confection]] molded from sugar paste. The design and construction of these figures can vary from region to region. Today, alfeñique figures, especially [[calavera]]s (known in the US as Sugar Skulls), are widely created in [[Mexico]] for the [[Day of the Dead]] celebrations in November.
==History== [[File:Borregos de dulce..JPG|thumb|Alfeñiques at the ''[[Alfeñique fair|Feria del Alfeñique]]'' in [[Toluca]].]] Alfeñique are folk art objects made from a sugar paste, originating in Italy where figurines were made from sugar for religious decorations. They became popular in Spain, wherefrom they were eventually brought to Mexico with Catholicism, where they became a part of Day of the Dead celebrations, starting around the 17th or 18th century.<ref name="cite2">{{cite web |url= http://www.celebrate-day-of-the-dead.com/mexican-sugar-skull.html |title=Mexican Sugar Skull |publisher=Thaneeya LLC |year=2010–2011 |accessdate=March 3, 2012 }}</ref> Alfeñique, whose name is from [[Arabic language|Arabic]] was used to replace the Aztec tradition of making figurines of [[amaranth]] for altars. The Spanish [[conquistador]]s brought sugar cane, which became the main ingredient in the making of these figurines which continues to this day.<ref name="pomar">{{cite book |author=[[María Teresa Pomar]] |year=2004 |title=Alfeñique |location= México |language=Spanish |publisher=CONACULTA |isbn=970-35-0578-3 }}</ref> During the colonial period, figures of sheep made with this were popular.<ref name="gmasters">{{cite book |editor1-first= Cándida |editor1-last= Fernández de Calderón |title= Great Masters of Mexican Folk Art: From the collection of Fomento Cultural Banamex |edition=2 |year=2003 |publisher= Fomento Cultural Banamex, A.C. |location=Mexico City |isbn=968 5234 09 4 |page=503 }}</ref>
Today, the main production center for alfenique figures are [[Toluca]], [[San Miguel de Allende]] and [[Guanajuato, Guanajuato|Guanajuato]]. Today, the paste is used to form hundreds of types of shapes which include rabbits, lions, ducks, doves, cows, bulls, donkeys, pigs, frogs, horses, deer, angels, skulls and coffins.<ref name="gmasters"/> The art form has taken on more elaborate sculptures that involve more sophisticated and modern techniques that there are now encyclopedic volumes on how to create them for all different occasions, apart from Day of the Dead celebrations.<ref name="mcgraw">{{cite book |year=2004 |title=Arte Mexicano del Azúcar: Enciclopedia Ilustrado |location= Ciudad de México |publisher=McGraw Hill |language=Spanish |editor1-first=Marithé |editor1-last=de Alvarado |isbn=970-10-3596-8 }}</ref> There are regional fairs and events that celebrate this art form, including [[Alfeñique fair|ones in Toluca, Mexico State]] and in Leon, Guanajuato.<ref name="cite5">{{cite web |url=http://www.leonguanajuato.com/galerias/alfenique.php |title=Feria Artesanal del Alfeñique, Mexico |publisher=Government of [[León, Guanajuato]] |accessdate=March 3, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303160813/http://leonguanajuato.com/galerias/alfenique.php |archive-date=2009-03-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="cite6">{{cite news |url=http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/d9cff78f9e4c88e6e0efd703f4ea180e |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130419011526/http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/d9cff78f9e4c88e6e0efd703f4ea180e |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 19, 2013 |title=Detallan actividades de la Feria del Alfeñique de Toluca |publisher=Milenio |location=Mexico City |date=September 28, 2010 |accessdate=March 3, 2012 }}</ref>
==Process== [[File:Calaveritas de dulce.jpg|thumb|Small alfeñique skulls]] The paste is prepared by mixing powdered sugar with chautle, a vegetable adhesive and lemon. Egg whites are beaten separately then folded into the sugar. Vegetable dyes are added for color. The unworked portion is covered with a damp cloth to keep it from hardening. Molds are prepared by carefully cleaning them, then dusting them with flour so the sugar mixture does not stick. The sugar paste is flattened into thin circles which are pressed into the molds, then left to dry for 24 hours<ref name="gmasters"/>
The two halves of the figure are then taken from the molds and joined together with more sugar paste, slightly thinned with water. This is left to dry again before decoration. Decorative elements can include cotton balls, sequins, sugar paste which is shaped and attached, plastic jewels and many other items<ref name="gmasters"/>
==Variations== The different regions make their alfeñique figures according to local traditions and ingredients. Many families have been involved in making figurines for generations and some use molds that go back just as far. Apart from their popularity during Day of the Dead celebrations, many families display the objects, particularly the skulls, in their homes.<ref name="pomar"/> In [[Oaxaca]], they commonly take the shape of skulls, crowns, crucifixes, the dead and are made from crystallized sugar with honey in the center. In the [[State of Mexico]], the most common objects are coffins, hearses, deer, sheep, angels, fruit, and skulls made of white sugar paste.<ref name="pomar"/> In [[Puebla]], the most common objects are skulls and coffins and the main ingredients include almonds, peanuts and pumpkin seeds mixed with sugar and egg, in the style of an almond paste.<ref name="peques">{{cite web |url= http://www.peques.com.mx/el_alfenique.htm |title=El alfeñique|publisher=CAD SA de CV |year=2010–2011 |accessdate=March 3, 2012 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Crafts of Mexico}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Alfenique}} [[Category:Mexican art]]

{{Taxobox | name = Armenian cochineal | image = Porphyrophora hamelii, female.jpg | image_caption = ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' (female) | image2 = Porphyrophora hamelii, male.jpg | image2_caption = ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' (male) | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Arthropod]]a | classis = [[Insect]]acar | ordo = [[Hemiptera]] | superfamilia = [[Coccoidea]] | familia = [[Margarodidae]] | genus = ''[[Porphyrophora]]'' | genus_authority = [[Johann Friedrich von Brandt|Brandt]], 1833 | species = '''''P. hamelii''''' | binomial = ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' | binomial_authority = [[Johann Friedrich von Brandt|Brandt]], 1833 | range_map = | range_map_width = | range_map_caption = | synonyms = *''Porphyrophora hameli'' <small>[[Johann Friedrich von Brandt|Brandt]], 1834 (revived by Jakubski, 1965)</small> *''Porphyrophora armeniaca'' <small>[[Hermann Burmeister|Burmeister]], 1835</small> *''Coccus radicis'' <small>[[Ernst Heinrich Friedrich Meyer|Meyer]], 1856</small> *''Margarodes hameli'' <small>[[Theodore Dru Alison Cockerell|Cockerell]], 1902 and [[Maria E. Fernald|Fernald]], 1903</small> *''Coccionella armeniaca'' <small>[[Karl Hermann Leonhard Lindinger|Lindinger]], 1954</small> *''Coccionella hamelii'' <small>[[Karl Hermann Leonhard Lindinger|Lindinger]], 1954</small> *''Coccionella hameli'' <small>[[Karl Hermann Leonhard Lindinger|Lindinger]], 1954</small> | synonyms_ref =  <ref name=ScaleNet_Porphyrophora_hamelii>{{cite web|url=http://scalenet.info/validname/Porphyrophora/hamelii/ |title=ScaleNet, Porphyrophora hamelii |last1=Ben-Dov |first1=Y. |last2=Miller |first2=D.R. |last3=Gibson |first3=G.A.P. |date=9 October 2014 |website=ScaleNet |accessdate=8 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025201637/http://scalenet.info/validname/Porphyrophora/hamelii/ |archivedate=25 October 2014 }}</ref> }}
The '''Armenian cochineal''' (''Porphyrophora hamelii'' <small>(Brandt)</small>), also known as the '''Ararat cochineal''' or '''Ararat scale''', is a [[scale insect]] indigenous to the [[Ararat plain]] and [[Aras River|Aras (Araks) River valley]] in the [[Armenian Highlands]]. It was formerly used to produce an [[eponym]]ous [[crimson]] [[carmine]] [[dye]]stuff known in [[Armenia]] as '''''vordan karmir''''' ({{lang-hy|[[wiktionary:որդան կարմիր|որդան կարմիր]]}}, literally "worm's red") and historically in [[Persia]] as ''kirmiz''.<ref name="ScaleNet_Porphyrophora_hamelii" /><ref name = "Ben-Dov_2005">{{cite book |last=Ben-Dov |first= Yair |date= 2005 |title= A Systematic Catalogue of the Scale Insect Family Magarodidae (Hemiptera: Coccoidea) of the World |location= United Kingdom |publisher= Intercept (Lavoisier) |isbn= 978-1-84585-000-5}}</ref><ref name = "Forbes_1964">{{cite book |last=Forbes |first= R.J. |date= 1964 |title= Studies in Ancient Technology |volume=IV |location= Leiden, Netherlands |publisher= E.J. Brill |isbn= 90-04-08307-3 |pages=102–103 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ua83AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA102#v=onepage&q&f=false|edition=2nd|orig-year=1956}}</ref><ref name="Donkin_1977">{{cite journal |last=Donkin |first=R.A. |date=1977 |title=The Insect Dyes of Western and West-Central Asia |jstor=40459185 |journal=Anthropos |publisher=Anthropos Institute |volume=72 |issue=5/6 |pages= 847–880 }}<!--|accessdate=9 October 2014--></ref><ref name="Vedeler_2014">{{cite book |last=Vedeler |first= Marianne |date= 2014 |title=Silk for the Vikings |location= Oxford, United Kingdom |publisher= OXBOW BOOKS |page= 52 |isbn= 978-1-78297-215-0}} Vedeler, citing Cardon (2007), notes that "the Persian name ''Kirmiz'' originally referred to the Armenian carmine, a parasitic insect living on Gramineae grass, but the same name was also used by Arab geographers for insects living on oak trees in Maghreb and Al-Andalus, probably referring to ''[[Kermes vermilio]]''", although "[i]t is ... not clear whether the 'Kirmiz' dyestuff mentioned in early Arab texts always refers to the use of the insect ''Kermes Vermilio''."</ref><ref name="Cardon_2007">{{cite book |last=Cardon |first= Dominique |date= 2007 |title= Natural Dyes: Sources, Tradition, Technology and Science |location= London, United Kingdom |publisher= Archetype Books |isbn= 978-1-904982-00-5}} English translation by Caroline Higgitt of Cardon's French-language book ''Le monde des teintures naturelles'' (Éditions Belin, Paris, 2003).</ref> The species is [[critically endangered]] within Armenia.<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham">{{cite web |url=http://www.mnp.am/red_book_fauna/eng/a65.html |title=Porphyrophora ham melii Brandt, 1833 |last=Khachatryan |first=H. |website=Red Book of Armenia |publisher=Ministry of Nature Protection, Republic of Armenia |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref>
The Armenian cochineal scale insect, ''Porphyrophora hamelii'', is in a different [[Family (biology)|taxonomic family]] from the [[cochineal]] found in the [[Americas]]. Both insects produce red dyestuffs that are also commonly called cochineal.<ref name="Eastaugh_etal_2007">{{cite book |last1= Eastaugh |first1= Nicholas |last2= Walsh |first2= Valentine |last3= Chaplin |first3= Tracey |last4= Siddall |first4= Ruth |date= 2004 |title= Pigment Compendium: A Dictionary of Historical Pigments |location= Oxford, UK and Burlington, MA |publisher= Elsevier Butterwoth-Heinemann |isbn= 0-7506-5749-9 |pages=118–119 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2OH28vpzzMsC&pg=PA118#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref>
== History and art == ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is one of the ancient [[Natural dye|natural sources]] of red [[dye]] in the Middle East and Europe, along with the insect dyes [[Kermes (dye)|kermes]] (from ''[[Kermes vermilio]]'' and related species), [[lac]] (from ''[[Kerria lacca]]'' and related species), and [[carmine]] from other ''[[Porphyrophora]]'' species such as the [[Polish cochineal]] (''Porphyrophora polonica''), and the plant dye madder (from ''[[Rubia tinctorum]]'' and related species).<ref name = Forbes_1964 /><ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Robinson_1969">{{cite book |last=Robinson |first=Stuart |date=1969 |title=A History of Dyed Textiles |location=London, United Kingdom |publisher= Studio Vista |isbn=978-0-289-79644-3}}</ref><ref name="Bohmer_and_Thompson_1991">{{cite journal |last= Böhmer |first= Harald |last2= Thompson |first2=Jon |date=1991 |title=The Pazyryk Carpet: A Technical Discussion |jstor= 23203293 |journal=SOURCE: Notes in the History of Art |publisher= Ars Brevis Foundation |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=30–36 }}<!--|accessdate=8 October 2014--></ref><ref name="Koren_2005">{{Citation |last= Koren |first= Zvi C. |date= 2005 |contribution=Chromatographic analyses of selected historic dyeings from ancient Israel |url= http://www.tekhelet.com/pdf/KOREN_2005_194-201.pdf |editor-last=Janaway | editor-first=R. |editor2-last= Wyeth |editor2-first=P. | title= Scientific Analysis of Ancient and Historic Textiles: Informing, Preservation, Display and Interpretation |location=London, United Kingdom |publisher= Archetype Publications |pages= 194–201 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Cardon_2010">{{Citation |last= Cardon |first= Dominique |date= 2010 |contribution=Natural Dyes, Our Global Heritage of Colours |url= http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/tsaconf/12/ |title= Proceedings of the 12th Biennial Symposium of the Textile Society of America ("Textiles and Settlement: From Plains Space to Cyber Space") (October 6–9, 2010) |location=Lincoln, Nebraska, USA |publisher= [[Textile Society of America]] |issue=Paper 12}}</ref><ref name="Kirby_2011">{{Citation |last= Kirby |first= Jo |date= 2011 |contribution=Dyes, Dyeing and Lake Pigments – Historical Background |url= http://www.doernerinstitut.de/downloads/Back_to_the_Roots/Back_to_the_roots_Kirby_I.pdf |title= ''Back to the Roots'' – Workshop on the Preparation of Historical Lake Pigments (March 23–25, 2011) |location=Munich, Germany |publisher= Doerner Institut |issue=Session T10.2: Organic colorants in ancient and contemporary art |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref> It is possible that Armenian cochineal dye was in use as early as 714 B.C., when the [[Neo-Assyrian Empire|Neo-Assyrian]] king [[Sargon II]] was recorded as seizing red textiles as spoils of war from the kingdoms of [[Urartu]] (the geographic predecessor of Armenia) and Kilhu.<ref name = "Forbes_1964" /><ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Thureau-Dangin_1912">{{cite book |last=Thureau-Dangin |first= François |date= 1912 |title=Une Relation de la Hutième Campagne de Sargon (714 av. J.-C.) texte Assyrien inédit, publié et traduit |language=French |location= Paris, France |publisher= Librairie Paul Geuthner |page= 57 |url=https://archive.org/details/unerelationdelah00thuruoft |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Phipps_2010">{{cite book |last=Phipps |first= Elena |date= 2010 |title=Cochineal Red: The Art History of a Color {{Square bracket open|1}}adapted from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin, v. 67, no. 3 (Winter 2010){{Square bracket close|1}} |location= New York City and New Haven, USA and London, UK |publisher= The Metropolitan Museum of Art and Yale University Press |isbn=978-0-300-19560-6 |page= |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/research/metpublications/Cochineal_Red_the_art_history_of_a_color# |accessdate= 8 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Kurdian_1941">{{cite journal |last=Kurdian |first=H. |date=1941 |title=Kirmiz |jstor= 594255 |journal=Journal of the American Oriental Society |publisher= American Oriental Society |volume=61 |issue=2 |pages=105–107 |doi=10.2307/594255}}<!--|accessdate=9 October 2014 --></ref> The [[Ancient Rome|Roman-era]] physician and pharmacologist [[Pedanius Dioscorides|Dioscorides]], writing in the 1st century A.D., noted that the best ''kokkos baphike'', the [[Quercus coccifera|kermes shrub]] and its "grain" ([[Kermes vermilio|kermes insect]]) that some ancient writers likely confused with ''Porphyrophora hamelii'', came from [[Galatia]] and Armenia.<ref name = "Forbes_1964" /><ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Dioscorides" >{{cite book |last=Obaldeston |first=T.A. |date=2000 |title=Dioscorides, ''De Materia Medica''. Five books in one volume: new modern English translation |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |publisher= IBIDIS Press |volume=4 |pages=588–591 |isbn=978-0-620-23435-1 |url=https://archive.org/details/de-materia-medica |accessdate=4 January 2015}} English translation by T.A. Obaldeston with introductory notes by R.P. Wood.</ref> In the [[Early Middle Ages]] the Armenian historians [[Ghazar Parpetsi]] and [[Movses Khorenatsi]] wrote specifically of a worm-produced dyestuff from the Ararat region.<ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Kurdian_1941" />
During the Middle Ages the Armenian cochineal dyestuff ''vordan karmir'', also known in Persia as ''kirmiz'', was widely celebrated in the [[Near East]].<ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Vedeler_2014" /><ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Kurdian_1941" /> ''Kirmiz'' is not to be confused with dyer's [[Kermes (dye)|kermes]], which was derived from another insect.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /> The Armenian cities [[Artashat (ancient city)|Artashat]] and [[Dvin (ancient city)|Dvin]] were early centers of the production of ''kirmiz'': during the 8th through 10th centuries [[Arabs|Arab]] and [[Persian people|Persian]] historians even referred to Artashat as "the town of ''kirmiz''".<ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Kurdian_1941" /> The Arabs and Persians regarded ''kirmiz'' as one of the most valuable commodities exported from Armenia.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /> The Armenians themselves used ''vordan karmir'' to produce dyes for [[textile]]s (including [[oriental rug]]s) and [[pigment]]s for [[Armenian illuminated manuscripts|illuminated manuscripts]] and church [[fresco]]s.<ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Kurdian_1941" /><ref name="Babenko_1988">{{cite journal |last=Babenko |first=Vitali |date=1988 |title=Vordan Karmir or Armenian Cochineal |url=http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-40.htm |journal=Oriental Rug Review |publisher=Oriental Rug Auction Review |volume=VIII |issue=5 |pages=40–41 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701123218/http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-40.htm |archivedate=2013-07-01 |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Mushak_1988">{{cite journal |last=Mushak |first=Paul |date=1988 |title=The use of insect dyes in Oriental rugs and textiles: Some unresolved issues |url=http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-33.htm |journal=Oriental Rug Review |publisher=Oriental Rug Auction Review |volume=VIII |issue=5 |pages=33–39 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701123218/http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-40.htm |archivedate=2013-07-01 |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref> Chemical analyses have identified the dye of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' in [[Copts|Coptic]] textiles of the 3rd through 10th centuries, a [[Cashmere wool|cashmere]] cloth used in a [[kaftan]] from [[Sasanian Empire|Sassanid Persia]] in the 6th or 7th century, silk [[Episcopal gloves|liturgical gloves]] from 15th-century [[France]], [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] fabrics such as [[velvet]]s and [[lampas]] of the 15th through 17th centuries, and a 16th-century velvet [[cap of maintenance]] that belonged to [[Henry VIII of England]].<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Petroviciu_etal_2012">{{cite journal |last1=Petroviciu |first1=Irina |last2=Crețu |first2=Ileana |last3=Vanden Berghe |first3=Ina |last4=Wouters |first4=Jan |last5=Medvedovici |first5=Andrei |last6=Albu |first6=Florin |last7=Creanga |first7=Doina |date=2012 |title=A discussion on the red anthraquinone dyes detected in historic textiles from Romanian collections |url=http://www.morana-rtd.com/e-preservationscience/2012/Petroviciu-29-02-2012.pdf |journal=e-Preservation Science |publisher=Morana RTD |volume=9 |pages=90–96 |accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref><ref name="Waterford_Treasures">{{cite web|title=Henry VIII's Cap of Maintenance|url=http://www.waterfordtreasures.com/medieval-museum/whats-inside/king-henry-viiis-cap-of-maintenance|publisher=Treasures of Medieval Waterford, Ireland: Medieval Museum|accessdate=28 November 2015}}</ref>
At the time of the [[Renaissance]] in Europe, ''Porphyrophora'' insects were so valuable that in [[Constantinople]] during the 1430s, {{convert|1|kg|lb|abbr=off|spell=in}} of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' insects was worth more than {{convert|5|g|oz|abbr=off}} of [[gold]].<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Cardon_2000">{{Citation |last= Cardon |first= Dominique |date= 2000 |contribution=Du verme cremexe au veluto chremesino: une filierè vénitienne du cramoisi au XVe siécle |language=French |editor-last=Molà | editor-first=L. |editor2-last= Mueller |editor2-first=R.C. |editor3-last= Zanier |editor3-first=C. | title= ''La Seta in Italia dal Medioevo al Seicento'' |location=Venice, Italy |publisher= Fondazione Giorgio Cini |pages= 63–73}}</ref><ref name="Cardon_2007_note2">Some articles improperly cite Cardon to suggest, incorrectly, that Armenian cochineal insects were more valuable, by weight, than gold (i.e., one gram of insects was worth several grams of gold) during this era. Cardon (2007) does, however, note that according to the records of a [[Venice|Venetian]] merchant trading in Constantinople during the 1430s, even the cheapest Armenian cochineal insects were still worth more, pound-for-pound, than some live [[Slavery|slaves]] ([[Circassians|Circassian]] women and adolescents) that he had bought.</ref> The [[crimson]] ''Porphyrophora''-based dyes were especially prized in Europe for dyeing [[silk]], as the [[Scarlet (color)|scarlet]] dye [[Kermes (dye)|kermes]] was more plentiful, cheaper, and more effective for dyeing [[wool]]en textiles, which are heavier than silk and require more dye.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /> It has been estimated that on the order of a half million dried ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' insects were required to dye {{convert|1|kg|lb|spell=in}} of silk crimson during this period.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Cardon_2007_note3">400,000 to 560,000 dried ''P. hamelii'' insects were required to dye 1 kg of silk according to the figures of Cardon (2007): 1,000 g to 1,400 g of dried insects per 100 g of silk, with 40 adult females per gram of dried insects. Note that Virey (1840) reports 18,000–23,000 insects per 360-gram troy pound (50–64 insects per gram; not stated whether they were dried).</ref> On the comparison between Armenian and Polish cochineal, the author of a 15th-century treatise on silks in [[Florence]] wrote that "two pounds of the large {{Square bracket open|1}}Armenian cochineal insects{{Square bracket close|1}} will dye as much {{Square bracket open|1}}silk{{Square bracket close|1}} as one pound of small {{Square bracket open|1}}Polish cochineal insects{{Square bracket close|1}}; it is true that it gives a more noble and brighter colour than the small, but it gives less dye."<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Gargiolli_1868_ed">{{cite book |editor-last=Gargiolli |editor-first=Girolamo |date=1868 |title=L'arte della seta in Firenze. Trattato del Secolo XV, pubblicato per la prima volta, e dialoghi raccolti da Girolamo Gargiolli. |language=Italian |location=Florence, Italy |publisher=G. Barbèra|page=32 |url=https://archive.org/details/lartedellasetai00garggoog |accessdate= 16 October 2014}}</ref>
Around the end of the 16th century the [[Old World]] ''Porphyrophora'' dyes were supplanted by dyes of the [[cochineal|''Dactylopius coccus'' cochineal]] species from the Americas, which could be harvested several times per year and yielded a much more concentrated dye.<ref name=Phipps_2010 />
The [[carmine]] dyestuff of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' owes its red color almost entirely to [[carminic acid]], making it difficult to distinguish chemically from the dyestuff of [[cochineal]] from the Americas.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Robinson_1969" /><ref name="Bohmer_and_Thompson_1991" /><ref name=Phipps_2010 /><ref name="Wouters_and_Verhecken_1989">{{cite journal |last=Wouters |first=Jan |last2=Verhecken |first2=André |date=1989 |title=The Coccid Insect Dyes: HPLC and Computerized Diode-Array Analysis of Dyed Yarns |jstor=1506286 |journal=Studies in Conservation |publisher=Maney Publishing |volume=34 |issue=4 |pages=189–200 |doi=10.1179/sic.1989.34.4.189}}<!--|accessdate=10 October 2014 --></ref> The dyestuff of ''Porphyrophora polonica'' can be distinguished by its small admixture of kermesic acid, which is the major constituent of [[Kermes (dye)|kermes]] from ''Kermes vermilio''.
In 1833 the German naturalist [[Johann Friedrich von Brandt]] suggested the [[Binomial name|scientific name]] ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' after the Russian physician, traveler, and historian of German descent Iosif Khristianovich Gamel (Josef Hamel) ([[:ru:Гамель, Иосиф Христианович|ru]]), who visited the Ararat plain in the early 1830s and wrote a report about the "cochineal" insects living there.<ref name="Brandt_Ratzeburg_1833">{{cite book |last=Brandt |first=Johann Friedrich |last2= Ratzeburg |first2=Julius Theodor Christian |date=1833 |title=Medizinische Zoologie oder getreue Darstellung und Beschreibung der Thiere, in der Arzneimitellehre in Betracht kommen, in systematischer Folge herausgegeben. |language=German |location=Berlin, Germany |publisher=Trowitzsch and Sohn|volume=2 |page=356 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZQPnKys-3mkC&pg=PA356#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=11 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Hamel_1833">{{Citation |last=Hamel |first=J. |date=1833 |contribution=Über Cochenille am Ararat und über Wurzelcochenille im Allgemeinen |contribution-url=http://publikationen.ub.uni-frankfurt.de/files/21947/E000014948.pdf |title=Mémoires de l'Académie Impériale des Sciences de St. Pétersbourg / Sciences mathématiques, physiques et naturelles |location=Frankfurt, Germany |publisher=Universitätsbibliothek Frankfurt am Main |language=German |volume=Tome III (1835) {{Square bracket open|1}}publishing the second part of Tome I (1833){{Square bracket close|1}} |issue=Série 6 |pages=9–64 |accessdate=11 October 2014}}. Publication of Hamel's 4 May 1833 report on the Ararat cochineal. Hamel's report mentions [[Johann Friedrich von Brandt|Brandt]].</ref>
<gallery mode="packed"> <!--Include photos of artwork (rugs, cloth, illuminated manuscripts, frescos, etc.) that have been definitively attributed to Armenian cochineal and not imported American or Polish cochineal, or kermes, madder, etc.--> File:Vordan Karmir (Cochineal Red) ornament on the ceiling of S. Grigor Chapel, Noravank monastery.jpg|''Vordan karmir'' ceiling art at [[Noravank|Noravank Monastery]] File:Խաչքար Գեղարդ27.JPG|''[[Khachkar]]s'' (cross-stones) at [[Geghard|Geghard Monastery]] painted with ''vordan karmir''<ref name="Geghard_Armenian_Monuments">{{cite web|title=Geghard 7: Monk cells, Khachkar Wall. Geghard's Khachkars.|url=http://www.armenianheritage.org/en/monument/Geghard/78|publisher=Armenian Monuments Awareness Project|accessdate=12 October 2014|quote=The red color found on some of the cross stones is a result of their being painted with Vortan Karmir, a red dye made from beetles native to Armenia. The red dye was among the more famous exports of the kingdom, and was valued more than gold in Europe and the Near East. Its resilience has long since proved itself; the color you see now is more than 800 years old.}}</ref> File:Saint Bertrand de Comminges-Gants et Chaussons.jpg|Silk [[Episcopal gloves|liturgical gloves]] (left) of [[Pierre de Foix, le vieux|Cardinal Pierre de Foix]] (15th century), dyed crimson with ''P. hamelii'' carmine<ref name="Cardon_2007" /> File:Armenian Stamp Karmin.jpg|A 2006 Armenian postage stamp depicting ''P. hamelii'' </gallery>
== Biology == [[File:Porphyrophora hamelii, cysts.jpg|thumb|''Porphyrophora hamelii'' cysts around the root of ''Aeluropus littoralis'']]
''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is a [[Sexual dimorphism|sexually dimorphic]] species.<ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007">{{cite journal |last= Vahedi |first= Hassan-Ali |last2= Hodgson |first2= C.J. |date= 2007 |title=Some species of the hypogeal scale insect Porphyrophora Brandt (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha: Coccoidea: Margarodidae) from Europe, the Middle East and Africa |journal= Systematics and Biodiversity |publisher= Taylor & Francis |volume= 5 |issue= 1 |pages= 23–122 |doi=10.1017/s1477200006002039}}<!--|accessdate=9 October 2014 --></ref><ref name="Foldi_2005">{{cite journal |last= Foldi |first= Imre |date= 2005 |title=Ground pearls: a generic revision of the Margarodidae ''sensu stricto'' (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha: Coccoidea) |url= http://zoologie.umh.ac.be/asef/pdf/2005_41_01/compact/Foldi_ASEF_2005_41_1_81_125_compact.pdf |journal= Annales de la Société Entomologique de France |series=New Series |publisher= Taylor & Francis |volume=41 |issue= 1 |pages= 81–125 |accessdate=9 October 2014 |doi=10.1080/00379271.2005.10697442}}</ref><ref name= "Jakubski_1965">{{cite book |last=Jakubski |first=Antoni Władysław |date= 1965 |title=A Critical Revision of the Families Margarodidae and Termitococcidae (Hemiptera, Coccoidea) |location=London, United Kingdom |publisher=Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History)}}</ref> The adult female, from which [[carmine]] is extracted, is oval-shaped, soft-bodied, crimson in color, and has large forelegs for [[Fossorial|digging]]. The females can be quite large for a ''Porphyrophora'' species: up to {{convert|10|–|12|mm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|7|mm|in|abbr=on}} wide.<ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /><ref name= "Jakubski_1965" /> It has been noted that one [[Troy weight|troy pound]] (360 grams) of cochineal insects requires 18,000–23,000 specimens of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'', but 100,000–130,000 specimens of the sister species [[Polish cochineal|''Porphyrophora polonica'']] (or 20,000–25,000 specimens of [[Cochineal|''Dactylopius coccus'']]).<ref name="Virey_1840">{{Citation |last= Virey |first= M.J.J. |date= 1840 |contribution= Remarks on the former uses of purple or scarlet colouring insects. New cochineal of Persia and Armenia. |editor-last=Watt |contribution-url= https://books.google.com/books?id=LKQwAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA209#v=onepage&q&f=false |editor-first= Charles |editor2-last= Watt, Jr. |editor2-first= John |title= The Chemist: Or, Reporter of Chemical Discoveries and Improvements, and Protector of the Rights of the Chemist and Chemical Manufacturer |location= London, United Kingdom |publisher= R. Hastings |volume= I |pages= 209–210}}</ref><ref name="Fennel_1842">{{Citation |last= Fennel |first= James H. |date= 1842 |contribution= On useful insects and their products |contribution-url= https://books.google.com/books?id=wTo5AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA295#v=onepage&q&f=false |editor-last= Watt | editor-first= Charles |editor2-last= Watt, Jr. |editor2-first= John |title= The Mirror of Literature, Amusement, and Instruction |location=London, United Kingdom |publisher= J. Limbird |volume= I |issue= 19 |pages= 295–296}}</ref> The adult male ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is a winged insect.
The life cycle of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is mostly [[Hypogeal|subterranean]].<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /><ref name="Foldi_2005" /> Newly hatched [[Nymph (biology)|nymphs]] emerge from the ground in the springtime and crawl until they find the [[root]]s of certain [[Poaceae|grassy plants]] that [[Halophyte|grow in saline soil]], such as [[Aeluropus|''Aeluropus littoralis''<!-- <small>(Gouan) Parl.</small>-->]] ({{lang-hy|որդանխոտ}} (genus ''Aeluropus''),<ref name="Babenko_1988" /><ref name="Sov_Arm_Encyc_Orient_Rug_Rev">{{cite journal |date=1988 |title=Vordan Karmir: The Red Worm (From the ''Soviet Armenia Encyclopedia'', Vol. 8, 1982, pp. 642–43) |url=http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-42.htm |journal=Oriental Rug Review |publisher=Oriental Rug Auction Review |volume=VIII |issue=5 |pages=42–43 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701164358/http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-42.htm |archivedate=2013-07-01 |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref> literally "worm's grass") and the common reed [[Phragmites|''Phragmites australis''<!-- <small>(Cav.) Trin. ex Steud.</small>-->]].<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /> The nymphs continue to feed on these roots throughout the spring and summer, forming protective [[pearl]]-like cysts in the process.<!--<ref name = "Ben-Dov_2005" /><ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /><ref name="Foldi_2005" /><ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" />--> From mid-September to mid-October adults emerge from the ground between 5 a.m. and 10 a.m. to mate.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Sov_Arm_Encyc_Orient_Rug_Rev" /><ref name="Cardon_2007_note4">Cardon (2007) cites her own field mission in Armenia in 1989 as well as the papers by Jakubski (1965) and Mktrtchian and Sarkisov (1985) for her description of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' biology, which states that the mating time is from 5 a.m. to 10 a.m. The ''Soviet Armenian Encyclopedia'' (1982) and the online ''Red Book of Armenia'' (which cites Mktchyan and Sarkisov (1985) and others) state that the mating time is from 6 a.m. to 11 a.m. Note that in 1982 and 1985 the emergence of the insects in early September would have been in Armenian Summer Time (UTC+5), whereas the Republic of Armenia has been on UTC+4 time year-round since 2012.</ref> The adult insects, lacking mouthparts, do not feed.<ref name="Foldi_2005" /> Adult males live for only a few days, but adult females can live longer, burrowing into the ground to lay their eggs.<ref name="Foldi_2005" />
== Habitat and conservation == [[File:Vordan Karmir Habitat.jpg|thumb|left|The historic habitat of ''Porphyrophora hamelii''. [[Vordan Karmir State Reservation]] is in red and the historic dye-producing cities [[Artashat (ancient city)|Artashat]] and [[Dvin (ancient city)|Dvin]] are in purple.]]
The red dye-producing insects of the Ararat plain were once plentiful: a 19th-century French traveler wrote that shepherds' flocks, when led to drink from the [[Aras River|Araxes (Araks) River]], would appear bloody from the insects.<ref name="Donkin_1977" /> In the mid-20th century the extent of occurrence in Armenia was {{convert|100|km2|abbr=on}} with a recorded distribution that included the [[Ararat Province|Ararat]] and [[Armavir Province|Armavir]] provinces in Armenia as well as the Turkish, Iranian, and Russian [[Caucasus]], but by the 1990s the extent of occurrence in Armenia had shrunk to about {{convert|20|km2|abbr=on}}, mostly in Armavir Province.<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /><ref name="REC-Caucasus_Armavir">{{cite web |url=http://www.rec-caucasus.org/Flash/PDF/AR/AR7.pdf |title=Political Administrative Region (marz): Armavir |website= Regional Environmental Center for the Caucasus (REC Caucasus) |accessdate=10 October 2014}}</ref> During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] period, [[desalination]] of the Armenian salt marshes to create "economic and agricultural regions", and the creation of lakes for [[Fishery|fisheries]], "severely restricted the {{Square bracket open|1}}habitable{{Square bracket close|1}} area for the insects and {{Square bracket open|1}}endangered their{{Square bracket close|1}} existence."<ref name="Sov_Arm_Encyc_Orient_Rug_Rev"/>
[[File:Vordan Karmir reserve.jpg|thumb|[[Vordan Karmir State Reservation]], Armenia]]
The population in Armenia resides almost entirely in the [[Vordan Karmir State Reservation]], a [[salt marsh|salt meadow]] habitat of {{convert|198.33|ha|abbr=on}} northwest of [[Arazap|Arazap village]] and {{convert|21.52|ha|abbr=on}} in the north of [[Jrarat, Armavir|Jrarat village]] established in 1987 near the Araks River border with [[Turkey]], plus a site southeast of [[Ararat (village), Armenia|Ararat village]] and a few patches of several [[hectare]]s elsewhere.<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Vordan_Karmir_Reservation_Statute_2003">{{cite web |url=http://www.arlis.am/DocumentView.aspx?DocID=48076 |script-title=hy:«Որդան Կարմիր» Պետական Արգելավայրի Կանոնադրությունը Հաստատելու Մասին |trans-title="Vordan Karmir" State Reservation Statute of Approval|date=July 12, 2003 |website=Armenian Legal Information System (ARLIS.am) |publisher=Government of the Republic of Armenia |accessdate=10 October 2014|quote=1. «Որդան կարմիր» պետական արգելավայրը (այսուհետ` արգելավայր) ստեղծվել է Հայկական Սովետական Սոցիալիստական Հանրապետության Մինիստրների խորհրդի 1987 թվականի փետրվարի 2-ի N 61 որոշմամբ` Հայաստանի Հանրապետության Արմավիրի մարզի աղուտ հողերի վրա: Արգելավայրն զբաղեցնում է 219.85 հեկտար տարածք, բաղկացած է երկու առանձին տեղամասերից` Արազափի գյուղական համայնքի հյուսիսարևմտյան մասում (198.33 հեկտար) և Ջրառատի գյուղական համայնքի հյուսիսային մասում (21.52 հեկտար)` Արարատյան հարթավայրում, ծովի մակերևույթից 835–850 մետր բարձրության վրա:|language=Armenian }}</ref><ref name="Hayastani_Azgayin_Atlas_A">{{Citation |date= 2007 |contribution= Էնդեմիկ Տեսակներ: Կենդանիներ [''Endemic Species: Animals''] |script-title=hy:Հայաստանի Ազգային Ատլաս |trans-title=Armenian National Atlas |location= Yerevan, Armenia |publisher= "Geodeziayi ev Kʻartezagrutʻyan Kentron" POAK |volume= I |isbn= 99941-0-176-5 |pages= 83 |url= http://www.cadastre.am/resources/atlasA/images/83.jpg |accessdate= 3 January 2015 |language= Armenian}}</ref> There have been no recent scientific reports on populations of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' outside the surroundings of Mount Ararat.<ref name="Cardon_2007"/>
''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is considered [[critically endangered]] within Armenia by meeting the following conditions: an [[Occupancy–abundance relationship#Measures of species geographic range|area of occupancy]] of less than {{convert|10|km2|abbr=on}}, plus severely fragmented occupancy or known to exist at only a single location, plus continued decline (observed, inferred, or projected) in the area of occurrence, area of occupancy, and area, extent, and/or quality of habitat; and an [[Occupancy–abundance relationship#Measures of species geographic range|extent of occurrence]] of less than {{convert|100|km2|abbr=on}} with the aforementioned conditions of continued decline.<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="IUCN_Red_List_Categories_Criteria_v3_1">{{cite report|date=9 February 2000 |title=IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria, Version 3.1, Second Edition |url=http://jr.iucnredlist.org/documents/redlist_cats_crit_en.pdf |publisher=International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Species Survival Commission |pages=16–17 |accessdate=10 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128190606/http://jr.iucnredlist.org/documents/redlist_cats_crit_en.pdf |archivedate=28 January 2016 }}</ref>
Threats to the ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' population in Armenia include the [[Land development|development of saline lands]], agricultural improvements, uncontrolled [[livestock]] grazing, and possibly [[climate change]].<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /> Natural foes of the species include [[Tyrophagus putrescentiae|mold mites]], [[Coccinellidae|lady beetles]]<!--Lithophilus (or Tetrabrachys) bipustulatus (see also [[wikispecies:Lithophilus]]) and Nephus bipunctatus (see also [[Nephus]])-->, [[harvester ant]]s<!--Messor rufitarsis and Messor caducus (see also [[Messor]]), Pheidole pallidula (see also [[Pheidole]])-->, and [[erratic ant]]s<!--Tapinoma (or Formica) erraticum (or erraticus, erratica)-->.<ref name="ScaleNet_Porphyrophora_hamelii" /><ref name = "Ben-Dov_2005" />
{{clear}}

{{italic title}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} '''''Behemoth''''', full title '''''Behemoth: the history of the causes of the civil wars of England, and of the counsels and artifices by which they were carried on from the year 1640 to the year 1660''''', also known as '''''The Long Parliament''''', is a book written by [[Thomas Hobbes]] discussing the [[English Civil War]]. Published [[List of works published posthumously|posthumously]] in 1681, it was written in 1668, but remained unpublished at the request of [[Charles II of England]].
==Background== ''Behemoth'' was written in 1668 as a follow-up to a previous and scandalous political work, ''[[Leviathan (Hobbes book)|Leviathan]]'' (1651). ''Leviathan'' is a representation of an ideal political world, and ''Behemoth'' has been considered to be a contrasting treatise on what happens when the very worst abuses of government come to pass.<ref>A. P. Martinich. ''Hobbes: A Biography''. (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1999), 323.</ref> Hobbes applied his understanding of the science of human nature to explain why the English Civil War came to pass. He was able to do this because he "did not make an impassable gulf between his rational understanding on the one hand and the particular events which he witnessed, remembered, or heard about on the other".<ref>Richard Peters. ''Hobbes''. (London: Penguin Books, 1967), 60.</ref> The book is written in the form of a discourse between two men. The first speaker, called only "A", is an eyewitness and possible insider to the events of the English Civil War. The second speaker, referred to as "B", is a student aiming to understand the breakdown in the government of England at that time.
Hobbes was refused permission by King [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] to publish ''Behemoth''. While the king recognised the correctness of the account of events and issues, he was concerned that the book would not be well received.<ref>[[Noel Malcolm]], ed. ''Thomas Hobbes: The Correspondence''. Vol. 2 1660–1679. (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1994), 771.</ref> Charles withheld his permission to publish, in the hope that Hobbes would avoid further scandal, and perhaps see his reputation as a thinker restored.
The manuscript for ''Behemoth'' was pirated and printed in unauthorised editions in Europe during the 1670s and in a letter to his friend [[John Aubrey]], Hobbes stated his disappointment with this turn of events.<ref name="Malcolm, 772">Malcolm, 772</ref> An official edition was released three years after Hobbes' death in 1679, by his literary agent William Crooke. According to [[Aloysius Martinich]], "after its initial success the book was relatively unread and unstudied until there was a resurgence of interest in it in the last quarter of the twentieth century".<ref>Martinich, 324.</ref>
''Behemoth'' is not entirely factual, accurate or literal in retelling of the events of the English Civil War but still has value for students of the history of thought or revolution. As Royce MacGillivray puts it:
{{cquote| "It is noteworthy, however, for the brilliance of the interpretation, the excellence of the prose, the revelation of what it was possible for a profoundly rationalist thinker to conclude about the religious issues of the war, and the interest of seeing this daring and powerful thinker, more fully than he had done elsewhere, apply his philosophy to the state of the catastrophe of the war."<ref>Royce Macgillivray. "Thomas Hobbes' History of the English Civil War – A Study of ''Behemoth''", <u>''Journal of the History of Ideas''</u>, Vol. 31, No.2, (Apr.-Jun. 1970), 179.</ref> }}
Hobbes instead is drawing on his memories of the events and on two other possible sources, both written by [[James Heath (historian)|James Heath]] around 1663.<ref>MacGillivray, 182.</ref> These are ''A Brief Chronicle of all the Chief Actions'' and the expanded ''A Brief Chronicle of the Late Intestine Warr''. It is possible they were simply used as prompts for Hobbes, already 80 years old when he wrote ''Behemoth''. According to MacGillivray very little material from these sources found its way directly into the text.
''The summation below is just that, a summation, and is only the most basic part of each section. No effort is made to correct any inconsistencies introduced into the discussion between the master and the student so that the information may be presented as it was written by Thomas Hobbes.''
== Preface: The Bookseller to the reader == The 1682 edition of the book begins with a note from William Crooke in answer to why he was publishing this edition. Hobbes had made Crooke the caretaker of his literary estate in July 1679.<ref name="Malcolm, 772"/> Crooke knew of the editions of ''Behemoth'' published in Europe and he reasoned that these editions did not show the work in the best possible light due to the many textual errors and omissions. It would therefore be best to publish an authorized edition to correct these errors and show the work as Hobbes wanted it to be read. Crooke had as his source a manuscript copy of the text given to him by Thomas Hobbes around 1670.<ref>Thomas Hobbes. ''Behemoth: The History of the Causes of the Civil Wars of England, and of the Counsels and Artifices by Which They Were Carried on from the Year 1640 to the Year 1660''. (New York: Burt Franklin, 1963), 2.</ref>
== Part One: Behemoth, or the Epitome of the Civil Wars of England == This is the longest section of the book and roughly covers the period 1640–1642.
The dialogue opens with the student asking the master how it was that a monarch as strong as Charles I should ever have had to face a rebellion. The master relates that a growing opposition to the crown was promoted by seven factions, each of them for their own ends and not in concert, who stoked the fires of rebellion. These factions were: Papists, Presbyterians, Independents including other sects of religious faith, those who were corrupted by their reading of the Latin and Greek classics, centres of commerce and trade such as London, those with no means of support who saw the war as a way to profit, and the lack of understanding as to the important role played by the monarchy in society.
The motivations of each of these groups and how they contributed to the Civil War is discussed by the master and the student throughout the first part of the book. This section has been considered anti-clerical in its leanings as none of the actions of the religious groups involved are shown in any sort of positive light.
The Papists wanted to condemn any ruler who did not offer compliance to the will of Rome. As Charles I was officially a Protestant, this was not popular. There were not many Papists in England at this time but they still had a voice that could be heard by their own adherents.
Presbyterian ministers did not like a king whose queen was a known and practising Catholic. This translated itself into speeches calling for the exile of the queen and other Papists. As Catholicism was already severely proscribed against in the late 17th century these calls for expulsion are not unexpected or difficult to understand.
The Independents and the other sects of the Protestant reformation were advocates of liberty and freedom in certain instances especially in the matter of religious choice. Provided an individual did not want to follow the Roman church their religious views would be tolerated by most of the Protestant groups.
The issue of an absolute monarchy was a crucial cause of the Civil War according to Hobbes. Many members of the House of Parliament who wanted a monarchy did not want it to be an absolute one. Instead they desired that it act in consultation with the house before taking action. Charles I did not see the powers of the crown as being answerable to any but God. Parliament then acted to withhold required funds from the King in his quest to defeat the rebellious Scots. The Scots, Hobbes tells us, were in arms over the practice of [[episcopacy]]. This weakened the power of the crown but Charles I drew on the nobility to supply the needed funds for the war. When this source ran out Charles turned to Parliament to raise the [[Ship Money]], a percentage of customs revenue given to the King for the upkeep of the navy, so that he could use these funds to continue the war against the Scots. Parliament declared that illegal and took the crown to court over the issue.
The universities are brought into the discussion at this point. They existed as places where one could learn the classics and supposedly sharpen their minds by doing so. Instead they did not have the wit to read the classics critically and took them at their face value. This translated into certain scholars advocating an idealised form of republic to their students. However they did not teach the many virtues of the monarch to their students who came to see the crown as irresponsible.
Hobbes reminds his student that obedience is all that is required to live a good and peaceful life. This obedience should extend to the crown as it does to God and one's parents but this is not what was preached by the Protestant clergy. Instead they advised disobedience of royal edicts such as the raising privately of funds for the king's use. When this directive for disobedience was coupled with the teachings of ancient rebellions as a way to remove so called despotic domains it left a fertile ground for revolution in England.
== Part Two: Both Sides Prepare for War== The second section picks up the conversation on the following day and discusses how those who sought rebellion now began to make preparations for it to come to pass.
The people of England had become accustomed to hear from those whom they trusted, namely the bishops and the members of Parliament, how corrupted the crown had become. Now the discussion turned to a supposed plot by the King and Queen to return the realm to the church of Rome. The king responded by banishing some who had written pamphlets and sermons suggesting this return to Catholicism. Parliament had three of them released and they were received triumphantly in London upon their return.
In an effort to further weaken the King Parliament sought to have removed those members who were supporters of the monarchy. To this end the house impeached the [[Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford|Lord of Strafford]] for treason to Parliament and had him beheaded. Next Parliament arrested and executed the [[William Laud|Archbishop of Canterbury]] for his preaching of the introduction of arbitrary government ruled in consultation of the bishops. This was opposed by many in Parliament but mainly by the Scots.
After this discussion Hobbes' master provides a history of the house of commons and its role in the governance of the realm. He reminds his student that the Parliament had always been an institution of counsel and not control over the monarchy. The present Parliament oversteps the ancient bounds imposed on it by its appointed role as representative of the people before the king.
The rising in Ireland of an army of Papist sympathies who busied themselves harassing and slaughtering Protestants becomes an issue before the Parliament. A truce is made with the king to arrange a militia to combat this uprising in Ireland. Charles I dismissed the charges of high treason but would not identify his informant in the commons. The solicitor general is accused of being an informer on the house and he flees to France to avoid the wrath of the Parliament.
Parliament next took control of the militia from the crown and insisted that no adherents of the Roman church be allowed to command the army being sent to Ireland. Parliament raised funds for this expedition by selling shares of land in the Irish [[Provinces of Ireland|province]] of [[Ulster]]. A small share, three pence on every acre, was reserved for the crown with the balance of the funds being set aside for Parliament. The king did not assent to this. Relations between the two sides once again broke down and the king issued a declaration that Parliament needed to be obedient to the established laws of the kingdom.
Both sides began to gather material and men for possible war. The Parliament sent a message to the king, a humble petition, with 19 propositions to prevent conflict. The nineteen points are:
# Ministers serving on the King's Privy Council must be approved by the House of Commons and Lords. # Matters that concern the public must be debated only by Parliament. # A number of high offices, those dealing with finances and laws of the kingdom, must be chosen with the consent of both houses of Parliament. # The King's children's education and raising should be committed to those approved of by Parliament. # Parliament shall approve of the marriage of the King's children to any person, from home or abroad. #All laws against Papists must be strictly enforced. #The vote of Papists in the Lords shall be taken away, and the children of Papists must receive a Protestant education. #A reformation of the Church government must be made in a manner advised by both houses. #The King will accept the ordering of the militia by Parliament. #Members of Parliament that have recently been removed from the house must be allowed to return. # Councilors and judges must take an oath to maintain certain Parliamentary statutes. # All judges and officers approved of by Parliament shall hold their posts on condition of good behaviour. # The justice of Parliament shall apply to all law-breakers, whether they are inside the country or have fled. # The King's pardon must be granted, unless both houses of Parliament object. # Parliament must approve the King's appointees for commanders of the forts and castles of the kingdom. # The unnecessary military attachment guarding the King must be discharged. # The Kingdom will formalise its alliance with the Protestant States of the United Provinces (the Dutch) to defend them against the Pope and his followers. # The King must clear the six members of Parliament of any wrongdoing. # New peers of the House of Lords must be voted in by both Houses of Parliament.
These nineteen points were rejected by the king as they would further weaken the authority of the crown. This left both Parliament and the king no choice but to go to war.
''See the related article [[Nineteen Propositions]] for a further discussion of this aspect of the English Civil War.
== Part Three: The English Civil War, Rise of Cromwell, and Execution of Charles I== The discussion again continues after a break and now turns to the matter of the Civil war itself. The student is concerned about what he sees as the inability of Charles I to stand up to the Parliament due to his overall lack of resources [[power of the purse|as Parliament has taken control of much of the necessary material]] to fight a war. The master reminds the student that the officers on the side of the crown were all well experienced men and that this was an advantage that the [[Roundhead|Parliamentarians]] did not have. As for money, neither side had much on hand. Some of the forces supporting the king took future credit while those supporting the Parliament were funded by an appeal to the cities and by the placing of levies on the towns.
As the wars continued [[turncoats|men on both side of the struggle changed side]]. This at first was to the detriment of the Parliamentary forces but in time some of those loyal to the king began to support the cause of the Parliament. This was despite the [[Royal Prerogative in the United Kingdom|king's ancient right]] to [[Commission of Array|call for arms]] in times of conflict from all land owners and high born people. The Parliamentarians had already abandoned most of the laws and so this most ancient call to arms for the king was largely ignored.
The progress of the wars showed that early on the victory was mainly had by the king's [[cavaliers]] over Parliament's forces. Mainly in the north and the west of the country Charles I had his successes. Scotland came into the war on the side of Parliament and this put some pressure on the crowns forces. This pressure was used by [[Oliver Cromwell]] in 1644 to win the [[Battle of Marston Moor]]. This marks the rise of Oliver Cromwell in the Parliamentary army and he would use these successes to eventually take over the control of the commonwealth as [[Lord Protector]].
In 1645 Cromwell reorganised Parliaments forces into the [[New Model Army]]. This was a more disciplined and better trained group of soldiers and with this the tide began to turn against the royalist cause. In 1646 the besieged Charles I received from Parliament the same nineteen points that had brought both sides to conflict. Charles again did not give assent to them. Instead an arrangement was brokered between Parliament and the king that would see him surrender himself to them and thus end the war. By the end of 1646 the great seal of the king was broken and power over England was now available to be taken.
1647 and 1648 saw the contention for control over the realm between Oliver Cromwell, with his [[New Model Army]], and the Parliament as the king was held prisoner and not permitted to govern. Cromwell controlled 55 members of the parliament and used them to gain further support for his control over the government. Cromwell made overtures to the king to gain those members who had supported the royalist cause. London tried to stand against Cromwell but was quickly put down. He continued to consolidate his power and eventually had control over the parliament. He did not turn control back to the king as he said he would.
Charles I was as unwilling to work with Parliament under the control of Cromwell and the generals as he had been before the Civil War. [[Pride's Purge|Cromwell removed opposition in the house]], leaving what became known as the [[Rump Parliament]], and began a charge against the king for his part in bringing about the war.
The king was brought before Parliament, [[High Court of Justice for the trial of Charles I|the charges read]], and the king denied the authority of Parliament to charge him. This occurred three times and each time [[List of regicides of Charles I|Parliament]] asserted that they did have the necessary authority. Charles was found guilty of tyranny and executed at the gates of Whitehall on 30 January 1649.
== Part Four: The Protectorship of Oliver Cromwell, Failure of Richard Cromwell, Restoration of the Stuarts== The Rump Parliament became an [[Oligarchy]] after the execution of Charles I. A [[English Council of State|forty-person council of state]], whose job was to carry out the directives of the [[Rump Parliament]], was established. The Parliament took the name ''Custodes Libertatis Angliae'' (Custodians of English Liberty) for use in legal matters. Hobbes saw this as being foolish as they did not have a good idea of what [[liberty]] actually meant.
Cromwell, not yet the sole head of the government, went with the army to [[Cromwellian conquest of Ireland|Ireland]] and in a year subdued the entire country. In Scotland the [[James Graham, 1st Marquess of Montrose|Earl of Montrose]] failed to get the people behind a rising against the Parliament and was executed. Cromwell's rival, [[Thomas Fairfax, 3rd Lord Fairfax of Cameron|General Fairfax]], resigned instead of taking an army into Scotland to fight fellow [[Covenanters|Presbyterian]]s. Cromwell was now made general of the entire army.
[[Charles II of England|Charles II]] went to Scotland, after agreeing to the demands of the [[Parliament of Scotland|Scots Parliament]] and sat as king. Hostilities between England and Scotland recommenced. Cromwell and the army invaded Scotland to capture the young king. Charles II, after failing to hold [[Edinburgh]] or [[Stirling]], was able to [[Escape of Charles II|escape to the Continent]].
The Rump responded to an altercation with the Dutch and it began the [[First Anglo–Dutch War]] in 1652. Cromwell continued to fight the enemies of England while he solidified his hold over the Parliament. Cromwell was able to dissolve Parliament on 23 April 1653. A [[Barebone's Parliament|new parliament]] was composed of 142 of Cromwell's staunchest supporters from the army and the old Parliament. He gave them supreme power, and they in return appointed him [[The Protectorate|Protector of England]]. The Dutch were [[Treaty of Westminster (1654)|defeated]] by the English, and Cromwell now had control of all of England.
In 1657 Cromwell was offered the title of king but refused it due to the opposition of the army, his source of power, to the idea. Parliament began to descend into disorder as factionalism again crept into its proceedings. Cromwell managed to keep the various factions in line.
After Cromwell's death the Parliament fell into disarray. [[George Monck, 1st Duke of Albemarle|General Monck]] saw that the only solution to the troubles was not to have [[Richard Cromwell]] succeed his father but to restore the monarchy. Monck occupied London with the army and forced parliament to offer the crown to Charles II. The monarchy was then [[English Restoration|restored]] when Charles II accepted the offer of the Parliament.
== Criticism of Hobbes' views on rebellion == [[Immanuel Kant]], one of the leading intellects of the [[Age of Enlightenment]], had a different view on the nature of rebellions from Hobbes. Howard Williams, of the [[University of Wales]], in 2003 wrote a study comparing the views of the two great thinkers on the subject of revolution amongst other things. Hobbes saw all revolution as something that should be avoided at all costs. Hobbes expressed society as a combination of the people, as the body of the society, and the monarchy, as the soul of the society, making a healthy commonwealth. Without the soul the body dies and so it is with society for Hobbes. Civil war should be avoided because it is "the process of a society losing its soul".<ref>Howard Williams. "Kant's Critique of Hobbes: Sovereignty and Cosmopolitanism", (Cardiff: University of Wales Press, 2003), 31.</ref> In this book Williams describes Hobbes writing of ''Behemoth'' as an attempt to "capture the spirit of those awful times and to suggest emphatically that they should not be repeated".<ref>Williams, 32.</ref> Hobbes did not believe that anything positive came out of the civil war.
Kant, according to Williams, shares the same basic attitude to the resistance of sovereign power but does not think that all outcomes of Rebellion are necessarily negative.<ref>Williams, 33.</ref> Kant is writing about the [[French Revolution]], not the English Civil War, in his book ''The Conflict of the Faculties''. Written more than 100 years after Hobbes wrote ''Behemoth'', it has as its focus the idea that rebellions arouse sympathy in other countries for the people caught up in them. Kant says that this is due to a "moral disposition within the human race".<ref>Williams, 34</ref> Going further Kant, according to Williams, implies that uprisings are the wrong solution to a problem with governance but that there can still be something positive in the results of that uprising.
Hobbes does not think that there is any sort of innate morality in society and that rebellion is either "an unwise or failed experiment as a complete blunder arising from ignorance".<ref>Williams, 34.</ref> Instead, according to Williams, Hobbes has sympathy not for the common people caught up in the rebellion but instead for those who were the victims of the rebellion. This is in keeping with the royalist stance taken by Hobbes in ''Behemoth''. '' The French Revolution was not the only source for Kant's views on rebellion. He took into account the [[American Revolutionary War]] and the English Civil war as well as the views of classical thinking on the nature of republics.<ref>Williams, 36.</ref> Hobbes, of course, could not do this. Kant as well was more of an observer than a participant in the events of these revolutions. Hobbes was deeply affected by the Civil war and believed that rebellion would not be a solution. Instead "only an absolute sovereign power could teach 'the science of just and unjust', fixing meanings in a stable way and thus inducing social cohesion".<ref>David Norbrook, "''The English Revolution and English Historiography''" in <u>The Cambridge Companion to Writing of the English Revolution</u>, Ed. N.H. Keeble, (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2001), 270.</ref>
Hobbes then is a supporter of an "absolute sovereignty, embodied in a monarch or corporate body of individuals; Kant is a supporter of popular sovereignty, embodied in the law-making powers of a group of the people's representatives".<ref>Williams, 37.</ref> Another key difference between the two philosophers is the way that the laws of the land should be administered. An absolute monarch, for Hobbes, implies that the authority of that monarch "must be beyond question, whereas for Kant the sovereign's authority is best safeguarded through the possibility of public debate and criticism".<ref>Williams, 38.</ref> These fundamental differences in thinking are perhaps more to do with the differences in the eras the two philosophers lived in. Hobbes lived a hundred years before Kant. Additionally Hobbes experienced rebellion first hand, even to the point of fleeing England for fear of his personal safety, whereas Kant did not directly suffer during the rebellions that occurred in his lifetime. Another consideration was that in the course of a century much more had been written on the subject of the rights of the people and of liberty and this too must have been an influence on Kant's point of view. This does not negate Hobbes' views on rebellion but does illuminate a probable cause for his position on them.
== References == {{Reflist}}

'''Bernhard Alexander''' (1850–1927) was a Hungarian writer of Jewish background, and a professor of philosophy and [[esthetics]].
==Life and career== Bernhard (Bernát) Alexander was born '''Alexander Márkus''' in [[Budapest|Pest]]<ref>The cities of Buda and Pest and the town of Óbuda were merged as the city of Budapest in the fall of 1873.</ref> on 13 April 1850, and educated in his native city, later attending German universities, where he pursued studies in the fields of [[philosophy]], [[aesthetics]] and [[pedagogy]]. On his return to Hungary he was appointed to a teaching post in a ''[[Realschule]]'' (scientifically oriented high school) in Budapest, and in 1878 was admitted as a docent into the faculty of philosophy at the [[University of Budapest]], where he became a full professor in 1895. From 1892, he also lectured on [[dramaturgy]] and esthetics at the National Theater Academy, and on the latter subject and on the history of civilization at the Francis Joseph Polytechnic. He was a corresponding member of the [[Hungarian Academy of Sciences]] and a member of the [[Kisfaludy Society]], a major force in Hungarian literature. He was the father of [[Franz Alexander]], a Hungarian-American psychoanalyst and physician, who is considered one of the founders of psychosomatic medicine and psychoanalytic criminology, and maternal grandfather of [[Alfréd Rényi]], a Hungarian mathematician who made contributions in combinatorics, graph theory, number theory but mostly in probability theory.
==Works== Alexander's chief works are ''A philosophia történetének eszméje, tekintettel a történetre általában'' (The idea of the history of philosophy, in consideration of history in general, 1878); ''[[Immanuel Kant|Kant]]. Élete, fejlődése és philosophiája'' (Life, development and philosophy, 1881); ''A XIX. század pesszimizmusa: [[Arthur Schopenhauer|Schopenhauer]] és [[Karl Robert Eduard von Hartmann|Hartmann]]'' (The pessimism of the 19th century: Schopenhauer and Hartmann, Budapest, 1884, prize essay). Alexander, together with Professor Józef Bánóczi, later edited a seminal series of books on philosophers, the ''Filosofiai Irók Tára'', for which he did translations and annotations of [[René Descartes]], [[David Hume]], and the ''[[Prolegomena]]'' to [[Immanuel Kant]]. Jointly with Bánóczi, he translated Kant's ''Critique of Pure Reason''. He was an active writer on matters of education, editing the pedagogical journal ''Magyar Tanügy'' from 1882 to 1886.
==Exile and death== However, Alexander became pariah in the nationalistic, anti-Semitic environment of [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)|post-1919 Hungary]] and [[Miklós Horthy|Miklós Horthy's government]], and spent four years abroad. He died in Budapest in 23 October 1927.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{JewishEncyclopedia}} and from the Hungarian Wikipedia page. *[https://books.google.com/books?id=ggciAQAAIAAJ&q=%22bernhard+alexander%22+1850+1927&dq=%22bernhard+alexander%22+1850+1927&lr=&ei=UyfGS-nIMJeuywSG-fTbDg&cd=10 Váltó- és keresztkapcsolások: a tudásközvetítés folyamatai a két világháború közti magyar és német nyelvű kultúrában] at Google Books
{{Authority control}}
