{{About|the series of paintings||Water lily (disambiguation){{!}}Water lily}} {{italic title}} [[File:Claude Monet - The Water Lilies - The Clouds - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|400px|[[Claude Monet]], ''The Water Lilies - The Clouds'', 1920–1926, [[Musée de l'Orangerie]]]] [[File:Claude Monet - The Water Lilies - Setting Sun - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|400px|Claude Monet, ''The Water Lilies - Setting Sun'', 1920–1926, Musée de l'Orangerie]] [[File:WLA moma Reflections of Clouds on the Water-Lily Pond Monet.jpg|thumb|400px|Claude Monet, ''Reflections of Clouds on the Water-Lily Pond,'' c. 1920, 200 × 1276 cm (78.74 × 502.36 in), [[oil on canvas]], [[Museum of Modern Art]], [[New York City]]]]
'''''Water Lilies''''' (or '''''Nymphéas''''', {{IPA-fr|nɛ̃.fe.a|lang}}) is a [[Serial imagery|series]] of approximately 250 oil paintings by French [[Impressionism|Impressionist]] [[Claude Monet]] (1840–1926). The paintings depict his [[Fondation Monet in Giverny|flower garden]] at [[Fondation Monet in Giverny|his home]] in [[Giverny]], and were the main focus of his artistic production during the last thirty years of his life. Many of the works were painted while Monet suffered from [[cataracts]].<ref name=A>"Monet, Claude." [[Grove Art Online]].</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Smart|first1=Alastair|title=Why are Monet's water-lilies so popular?|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-features/11167000/Why-are-Monets-water-lilies-so-popular.html|website=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=2 November 2016|date=18 October 2014}}</ref>
==Background== Monet's long preference for producing and exhibiting a series of paintings related by subject and perspective began in 1889, with at least ten paintings done at the ''Valley of the Creuse'', which were shown at the Galerie Georges Petit.<ref>Tucker, Paul Hayes, ''Monet in the '90s: The Series Paintings'', 1989, [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]] in association with [[Yale University Press]], p.41.</ref> Among his other famous series are his ''[[Haystacks (Monet)|Haystacks]]''.
During the 1920s, the state of France built a pair of oval rooms at the [[Musée de l'Orangerie]] as a permanent home for eight water lily [[mural]]s by Monet. The exhibit opened to the public on 16 May 1927, a few months after Monet's death.<ref name="A"/> Sixty water lily paintings from around the world were assembled for a special exhibition at the Musée de l'Orangerie in 1999.<ref>Susan Bell. "Paris sees Monet lilies in a new light." ''[[The Times]]''. 8 May 1999.</ref>
The paintings are on display at museums all over the world, including the [[Princeton University Art Museum]], [[Musée Marmottan Monet]],<ref>[http://www.marmottan.fr/fr/claude_monet-musee-2517 Claude Monet paintings] at the Marmottan</ref> the [[Musée d'Orsay]] in Paris, the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York,<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search?ft=monet Water Lilies] at the Metropolitan Museum of Art</ref> the [[Art Institute of Chicago]],<ref>[http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/artwork/artist/Monet%2C+Claude Water Lilies] at the Art Institute of Chicago</ref> the [[Saint Louis Art Museum]],<ref>[http://www.slam.org/emuseum/code/emuseum.asp?style=single&currentrecord=1&page=seealso&profile=objects&searchdesc=The%20Promenade%20with%20the%20Rail...&searchstring=id/,/is/,/7056/,/false/,/true&newvalues=1&rawsearch=id/,/is/,/1930/,/false/,/true&newstyle=single&newprofile=objects&newsearchdesc=Water%20Lilies&newcurrentrecord=1&module=objects Water Lilies] at the Saint Louis Art Museum,</ref> the [[Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art]] in Kansas City, Missouri,<ref>[http://www.nelson-atkins.org/art/CollectionDatabase.cfm?id=6650&theme=euro Water Lilies], the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art</ref> the [[Carnegie Museum of Art]], the [[National Museum of Wales]], the [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Nantes]], the [[Cleveland Museum of Art]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clevelandart.org/art/1960.81 |title=Water Lilies (Agapanthus) |publisher=Cleveland Museum of Art |date= |accessdate=2013-01-31}}</ref> the [[Portland Art Museum]] and the [[Legion of Honor (museum)|Legion of Honor]].<ref>[http://www.famsf.org/]</ref>
==The paintings at auction== On 19 June 2007, one of Monet's water lily paintings sold for £18.5 million at a [[Sotheby's]] auction in [[London]].<ref>Dalya Alberge. "Monet lilies make £18.5m but just miss world record." ''The Times''. 20 June 2007.</ref> On 24 June 2008 another of his water lily paintings, ''[[Le Bassin Aux Nymphéas]]'', sold for almost £41 million at [[Christie's]] in [[London]], almost double the estimate of £18 to £24 million.<ref>[http://www.xmotu.com/laurahenrycollection/news_monet.html The Laura Henry Collection] "Monet masterpiece sells at auction for almost £41million" ''The Laura Henry Collection''. 25 June 2008.</ref>
In May 2010, it was announced that the 1906 ''Nymphéas'' work would be auctioned in [[London]] in June 2010. The painting had an estimated sale price of between £30 and £40 million.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10225556.stm|title=Monet water lily to be auctioned at Christie's|date=3 June 2010|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=BBC|accessdate=3 June 2010}}</ref> Giovanna Bertazzoni, [[Christie's]] auction house director and head of impressionist and modern art, said, "Claude Monet's water-lily paintings are amongst the most recognised and celebrated works of the 20th Century and were hugely influential to many of the following generations of artists."<ref name="BBC"/> The sale took place on 23 June 2010 at the auction house and the painting attracted bids of up to £29 million, but it ultimately failed to sell.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10396341.stm|title=Picasso reaches £34.7m in Christie's auction|date=24 June 2010|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=26 June 2010}}</ref>
On 6 May 2014, one of the Water Lilies paintings was auctioned at Christie's, New York City for $27 million.[16] This auction totaled $141 millon <ref>https://news.artnet.com/market/christies-141-million-impressionist-evening-sale-496091</ref> with the Monet piece Le bassin aux nymphéas being auctioned for $27 million of this amount.
In June of 2014, one of the Water Lilies, ''Nymphéas'', sold for $54 million USD at a Sotheby's auction in London.<ref>http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-monet-painting-auction-20140626-story.html</ref> This piece was auctioned to an anonymous buyer, but the piece went on to be part of the exhibition "Painting the Modern Garden: From Monet to Matisse" at the Cleveland Museum of Art and the Royal Academy of Arts, London, starting in 2015.<ref>http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-monet-painting-auction-20140626-story.html</ref> The co-chairman of Sotheby's modern and impressionist art department, Helena Newman, claims that the result is at the top of the original estimated selling price. This price was between 34 and 51 million USD.
While many of Monet’s masterpieces have sold, there are still an estimated 250 oil paintings from this series.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/claude-monet-water-lilies-sell-for-32m-in-second-highest-auction-sale-for-his-work-9558624.html</ref> The collection is widely popular, with many of these pieces residing in exhibits that have yet to go to auction.

[[Image:猴貓圖.jpg|thumb|Yi Yuanji, "Monkey and Cats" (fragment)]] '''Yi Yuanji''' ({{zh|c=易元吉}}; [[Wade-Giles]]: '''I Yüan-chi''') (c. 1000, [[Changsha]], [[Hunan]]<ref name=gov>[http://tech2.npm.gov.tw/english/dm/painting/selection/info/mainA-05.htm I Yüan-chi]</ref> – c. 1064) was a [[Northern Song Dynasty]] painter, famous for his realistic paintings of animals. According to [[Robert van Gulik]], Yi Yuanji's paintings of [[gibbon]]s were particularly celebrated.<ref name=gulik>[[Robert van Gulik|Van Gulik, Robert Hans]] (1967), The gibbon in China: An essay in Chinese animal lore, E. J. Brill, Leiden, Holland. There is a brief summary at [http://www.gibbons.de/main/introduction/chapter_english08.html]</ref> <ref>Thomas Geissmann, [http://www.gibbonconservation.org//07_journal/gibbon_journal_4.pdf Gibbon paintings in China, Japan, and Korea: Historical distribution, production rate and context"] . ''Gibbon Journal'', No. 4, May 2008.</ref>
The 11th-century critic [[Guo Ruoxu]] (郭若虚) in his "Overview of Painting" (图画见闻志, ''Tuhua Jian Wen Zhi'') tells this about Yi's career:<ref>English translation by Van Gulik, in Van Gulik (1967), p. 79</ref><ref>Guo Ruoxu's text is also in [http://www.esgweb.net/Article/Class138/Class161/Class165/200702/12045_5.htm this article] {{zh icon}}</ref> {{quotation|... His painting was excellent: flowers and birds, bees and [[cicada]]s he rendered life-like with subtle detail. At first he specialized in flower and fruit, but after he had seen such paintings by [[Zhao Chang]] (趙昌), he admitted their superiority with a sigh, and then resolved he would acquire fame by painting subjects not yet tried by the artists of old; thus he began to paint roebucks and gibbons.}} He spent months roaming the mountains of southern [[Hubei]] and northern [[Hunan]], watching [[Roe Deer|roebuck]]s (獐鹿) and gibbons (猿狖) in their natural environment.<ref name=gulik/>
[[Image:Yi-Yuanji-Fan-painting-Two-gibbons.jpg|thumb|A gibbon picture on a fan by Yi Yuanji]] In 1064, Yi Yuanji was invited to paint screens in the imperial palace. Once this job has been completed, the [[Emperor Yingzong of Song|Yingzong Emperor]], impressed, commissioned him to paint the "Picture of a Hundred Gibbons", but unfortunately the artist died after painting only a few gibbons.<ref name=gov/><ref name=gulik/> A few of his other gibbon paintings have survived, and [[Robert van Gulik]], quite familiar with the behavior of this ape, comments on how naturally they look in the pictures.<ref name=gulik/> His other work includes depictions of deer, peacocks, birds-and-flowers and fruits-and-vegetables; many of them are kept in the [[National Palace Museum]] in [[Taipei]].<ref name=gov/> The "Monkey and Cats" painting is especially charming.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,809434-3,00.html MASTERPIECES OF CHINESE ART], [[Time Magazine]], May 6, 1957</ref> Van Gulik identifies the monkey as a [[macaque]].<ref name=gulik/> This painting was featured on a 2004 "Year of the Monkey" stamp from [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]].<ref>[http://www.purr-n-fur.org.uk/philately/archive/review-04-2.html Feline Philately: Cats on stamps]</ref>
The image of Yi Yuanji, with his intimate knowledge of nature, has attracted attention from modern Chinese painters.<ref>Painting by modern artist Fan Zeng (范曾) [http://auction.sc001.com.cn/detail_auction.asp?id=591600 "Yi Yuanji playing with a monkey (易元吉戏猴图)"], painting by the modern Chinese artist Fang Zeng (范曾)</ref>
